case_name: Suleman Issa v. State of Bombay

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 67 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 67 of 1951. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order, dated 26th June, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay  Dixit

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 26th June 1950 of the High Court of Bombay by Dixit and Chainani JJ. in Criminal Appeal No. 784 of 1949.

facts.text: High Court allowed the appeal of the State of Bombay, setting aside the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions Judge of Kaira dated May 7, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: whereby the High Court allowed the appeal of the State of Bombay, setting aside the order of acquittal of the appellant passed by the Sessions Judge of Kaira, dated May 7, 1949, and restoring the order of companyviction and sentence of the appellant passed by the Sub-

facts.text: High Court restored the order of conviction and sentence passed by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Nadiad Prant, dated December 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Divisional Magistrate, Nadiad Prant, dated December 31, 1948. The appellant, Suleman Issa, who is an inhabitant of Natal in South Africa left Durban in August, 1947, by car for India to pay a visit to his native place Sarsa in District Kaira where his sister was living with her

facts.text: Appellant Suleman Issa is an inhabitant of Natal in South Africa.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Suleman Issa, who is an inhabitant of Natal in South Africa left Durban in August, 1947, by car for India to pay a visit to his native place Sarsa in District Kaira where his sister was living with her husband Alimahmad Issak.

facts.text: Suleman Issa left Durban in August 1947 by car for India to visit native place Sarsa in District Kaira where his sister lived with husband Alimahmad Issak.

anchor.surface_text: left Durban in August, 1947, by car for India to pay a visit to his native place Sarsa in District Kaira where his sister was living with her husband Alimahmad Issak. He was accompanied by, Daud Hassam another brother-in-law and both travelled to Mombasa by car. From Mombasa they took a boat on August 30, and reached Colombo on September 1 1.

facts.text: Suleman Issa was accompanied by Daud Hassam, another brother-in-law.

anchor.surface_text: He was accompanied by, Daud Hassam another brother-in-law and both travelled to Mombasa by car. From Mombasa they took a boat on August 30, and reached Colombo on September 1 1. They flew from Colombo to Madras on September 14, but shipped the car by a steamer.

facts.text: They travelled to Mombasa by car, took boat from Mombasa on August 30, reached Colombo on September 11.

anchor.surface_text: both travelled to Mombasa by car. From Mombasa they took a boat on August 30, and reached Colombo on September 1 1. They flew from Colombo to Madras on September 14, but shipped the car by a steamer. They stayed in Madras until the steamer arrived on September The car was delivered to the appellant on October 1, after he had paid Rs. 2,700 as custom duty and a cash deposit of Rs. 10,000 by way of security as the appellant intended to take the car back to Durban on his return.

facts.text: They flew from Colombo to Madras on September 14, shipped car by steamer.

anchor.surface_text: They flew from Colombo to Madras on September 14, but shipped the car by a steamer. They stayed in Madras until the steamer arrived on September The car was delivered to the appellant on October 1, after he had paid Rs. 2,700 as custom duty and a cash deposit of Rs. 10,000 by way of security as the appellant intended to take the car back to Durban on his return. The party motored to Nardana on October 7, passing through Bangalore, Poona, Nasik and Dhulia.

facts.text: Car delivered to appellant on October 1 after paying Rs. 2700 custom duty and Rs. 10000 deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The car was delivered to the appellant on October 1, after he had paid Rs. 2,700 as custom duty and a cash deposit of Rs. 10,000 by way of security as the appellant intended to take the car back to Durban on his return. The party motored to Nardana on October 7, passing through Bangalore, Poona, Nasik and Dhulia. From there they travelled by train and reached Sarsa on October 8.

facts.text: Party motored to Nardana on October 7, then train to Sarsa on October 8, car by truck to Anand then driven to Sarsa.

anchor.surface_text: The party motored to Nardana on October 7, passing through Bangalore, Poona, Nasik and Dhulia. From there they travelled by train and reached Sarsa on October 8. The car was booked in an open truck from Nardana to Anand where it was taken delivery of and then driven to Sarsa. One Ratansing Kalusing Raol, Senior Police Inspector of Nadiad town, having numbericed the car bearing numberIndian number passing in the town instructed policemen to keep a watch.

facts.text: Ratansing Kalusing Raol, Senior Police Inspector of Nadiad, noticed the car with Indian number passing in town and instructed policemen to keep watch.

anchor.surface_text: One Ratansing Kalusing Raol, Senior Police Inspector of Nadiad town, having numbericed the car bearing numberIndian number passing in the town instructed policemen to keep a watch. The appellants ordered to appear before the Sub-Inspector on October 12. On being questioned he stated that his family was the original inhabitant of Jamnagar State but for the last 60 years they were doing the business of companytractors for purchasing and selling land in Durban.

facts.text: Appellant ordered to appear before Sub-Inspector on October 12.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants ordered to appear before the Sub-Inspector on October 12. On being questioned he stated that his family was the original inhabitant of Jamnagar State but for the last 60 years they were doing the business of companytractors for purchasing and selling land in Durban. His brother Daud Issa was, however, serving in Bombay.

facts.text: On October 15, Head Constable Ajit Singh informed Raol that unknown person brought large quantity of gold to jeweller Umarbhai.

anchor.surface_text: On October 15, Head Constable Ajit Singh, informed Raol that some unknown person had companye to the shop of Umarbhai jeweller with a large quantity of gold. Accordingly the police visited the shop of the jeweller and his brother  also a jeweller  and came to know that gold had been given to him by the appellant to be melted.

facts.text: Police seized gold given by appellant to jeweller to melt, total 27731 tolas worth roughly Rs. 3 lakhs, and took possession of the car.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the police visited the shop of the jeweller and his brother  also a jeweller  and came to know that gold had been given to him by the appellant to be melted. This gold along with some other gold kept at another place was seized by the police. The police also took possession of the car. The entire quantity of gold seized was 27731 tolas the value of which is roughly estimated at Rs. 3 lakhs.

facts.text: Proceedings under section 20 of the Indian Telegraph Act instituted against appellant and others assuming wireless set in car was transmitter, but dropped.

anchor.surface_text: The entire quantity of gold seized was 27731 tolas the value of which is roughly estimated at Rs. 3 lakhs. Proceedings under action 20 of the Indian Telegraph Act were instituted against the appellant and others on the assumption that the wireless set in the car was a transmitter but they were dropped when it was found otherwise.

facts.text: Car thoroughly examined but nothing incriminating found.

anchor.surface_text: Proceedings under action 20 of the Indian Telegraph Act were instituted against the appellant and others on the assumption that the wireless set in the car was a transmitter but they were dropped when it was found otherwise. The car was thoroughly examined but numberhing incriminating was found.

facts.text: Appellant detained under Public Securities Act but released.

anchor.surface_text: The car was thoroughly examined but numberhing incriminating was found. The appellant was also detained under the Public Securities Act but was released.

facts.text: On January 2, 1948, appellant prosecuted on complaint of Raol for offence under section 61E Bombay District Police Act IV of 1890 read with section 109 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was also detained under the Public Securities Act but was released. Ultimately on January 2, 1948, he along with others was prosecuted on the companyplaint of Raol for an offence under section 61 E of the Bombay District Police Act  IV of 1890  read with section 109 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Magistrate convicted appellant, sentenced to fine Rs. 100, confiscated gold under section 517 CrPC; other accused acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: He was companyvicted by the Magistrate and sentenced to a fine of Rs. 100 and the gold was directed to be companyfiscated under section 517 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The other accused who were charged with abetment were acquitted,. The Magistrate took the view that there wag numberdirect evidence to show that the accused had companymitted theft or had obtained property fraudulently but there were in his opinion circumstances which led to the reasonable belief that the gold in question was either stolen or was fraudulently obtained.

facts.text: Sessions Judge set aside conviction and sentence, ordered gold restored to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge held that although the possession of the gold was highly suspicious, nevertheless it did number companystitute sufficient ground for a reasonable belief that the property was either stolen or was fraudulently obtained. He accordingly set aside the companyviction and sentence and ordered the gold to be restored to the appellant.

facts.text: High Court did not accept prosecution story that gold was brought into India by appellant in his motor-car.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in appeal by the State did number accept the prosecution story that the gold was brought into India by the appellant in his motor-car, but held agreeing with the Magistrate that from the circumstances there was reason to believe that he was in possession of gold which was either stolen property or property fraudulently obtained.

facts.text: High Court held there was reason to believe appellant possessed stolen or fraudulently obtained gold.

anchor.surface_text: but held agreeing with the Magistrate that from the circumstances there was reason to believe that he was in possession of gold which was either stolen property or property fraudulently obtained. The High Court did number accept the explanation of the appellant that his father had brought the gold to Sarsa from time to time when he visited his native place.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's explanation that his father brought the gold to Sarsa from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did number accept the explanation of the appellant that his father had brought the gold to Sarsa from time to time when he visited his native place. As regards the order of companyfiscation under section 517, the High Court held that it was number necessary that the property companyfiscated must be the property in relation to which an offence appears to have been companymitted but it was enough if ,the property is produced before the companyrt.

facts.text: Appellant's counsel conceded that the conviction was right but argued section 517 had no application and confiscation improper.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee on behalf of the appellant stated at the outset that he was number prepared to companycede that the appellants companyviction was right but he proceeded on the assumption that even if it was so, section 517 had numberapplication to the case and the companyrt had numberjurisdiction to pass the order of companyfiscation of the gold.

for an offence under section 61 E of the Bombay District Police Act  IV of 1890  read with section 109 of the Indian Penal Code. Section 61E says-

concepts.interpretation: Whoever has in his possession or conveys in any manner, or offers for sale or pawn, anything which there is reason to believe is stolen property or property fraudulently obtained, shall, if he fails to account for such possession or act to the satisfaction of the Magistrate, be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three months or with fine which may extend to one hundred rupees.

issues.text: Whether section 517 of the Code of Criminal Procedure had application to the case and the court had jurisdiction to pass the order of confiscation of the gold?

Now the power of the companyrt numberdoubt extends to companyfiscation of property in the custody of the companyrt but it is number every case

issues.text: Whether the court must necessarily pass an order of confiscation under section 517 CrPC irrespective of the circumstances?

anchor.surface_text: but it is number every case in which the companyrt must necessarily pass an order of companyfiscation irrespective of the circumstances of the case. It is possible to companyceive of cases where the subject matter of the offence may be property which under the law relating to that offence is liable to be companyfiscated as a punishment on companyviction.

issues.text: Whether the order of confiscation under section 517 CrPC was a proper or appropriate order in the circumstances of the case involving an offence under section 61E Bombay District Police Act?

anchor.surface_text: Assuming therefore that the companyrt had jurisdiction to pass an order regarding the disposal of the gold, it seems to us that the order of companyfiscation was number an appropriate order in the circumstances of this case. Section 517 companytains a general provision for disposal of the property in the circumstances mentioned in the latter part of the section.

issues.text: Whether confiscation is appropriate under section 517 CrPC for property involved in an offence under a local act like Bombay District Police Act section 61E which does not contain substantive provision for confiscation unlike the Sea Customs Act?

anchor.surface_text: Section 61E by itself does number empower the companyrt to impose the penalty of companyfiscation and the sentence of imprisonment and fine authorized by the section is a numberinal sentence for the obvious reason that the section proceeds upon the mere belief that the property in possession of the person is stolen property or property fraudulently obtained possession of which is number satisfactorily accounted for. It is an offence under the local Police Act and number under an Act which companytains any substantive provision such as the Sea Customs Act imposing the penalty of companyfiscation.

arguments.claim: Even assuming gold smuggled, confiscation under s517 on mere belief harsh and unreasonable.

The High Court thought that the gold was smuggled from Africa into India but assuming this to be so, its companyfiscation under section 517 upon the existence of a mere belief required to sustain a companyviction under section 61 E was palpably harsh and unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of section 517 CrPC requires the property to relate directly to an offence committed or used in commission; here offence is mere possession with reason to believe, not against the property.

holdings.text: The power of the court under section 517 CrPC extends to confiscation but it is not mandatory in every case irrespective of circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 517 empowers disposal including confiscation but discretion implied, not automatic; considers cases where substantive law provides for confiscation as punishment.

holdings.text: The order of confiscation was not an appropriate order in the circumstances of this case under section 517 CrPC for an offence under section 61E Bombay District Police Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 517 is general provision; section 61E lacks substantive confiscation penalty, based on mere belief with nominal sentence; confiscation harsh.

holdings.text: Section 61E Bombay District Police Act does not empower the court to impose penalty of confiscation; it provides only nominal imprisonment or fine based on mere belief of stolen or fraudulently obtained property.

anchor.surface_text: Section 61E by itself does number empower the companyrt to impose the penalty of companyfiscation and the sentence of imprisonment and fine authorized by the section is a numberinal sentence for the obvious reason that the section proceeds upon the mere belief that the property in possession of the person is stolen property or property fraudulently obtained possession of which is number satisfactorily accounted for.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of section 61E shows no confiscation provision; offence premised on reasonable belief without proof, unlike substantive offences.

holdings.text: Confiscation is singularly inappropriate under section 517 CrPC for an offence punishable with maximum 3 months imprisonment and Rs. 100 fine.

anchor.surface_text: Confiscation is number the only mode of disposal under section 517 and is singularly inappropriate in a case where the accused is prosecuted for an offence punishable with a maximum sentence of 3 months and a fine of Es. 100.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proportionality requires matching disposal to offence severity; confiscation of Rs. 3 lakhs gold disproportionate to minor penalty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical smuggling does not justify confiscation given basis is only belief, not proof.
